reviewText:
It just doesn't feel fun to play with the control scheme it has.

This game does not let you aim independently from your movement like a normal dual stick or WASD+mouse or WASD+arrows shooter. There are strafe and stand modifier buttons that allow you to lock the direction of either movement or aiming while held down, and that is the only way to do one without doing the other.

Furthermore, controllers are more capable than the keyboard setup because the game allows you to disable 8-way aiming on the thumbstick; and since there is no mouse aiming, this is impossible on a keyboard because you are only allowed 8 directions over 4 keys. Same goes for movement, though every game is like that.

I'm sure people are thinking, Dude
date: you're just not good enough." Well
recommended: I seem to be surviving just fine
hoursPlayed: so that's not it. "It was intentionally designed like that as a throwback to games like Gauntlet." The games it's throwing back to were from a period where design philosophy wasn't as refined as it is now. It's especially hard to understand such design choices since these problems have been solved for quite some time.\n\nI'm going to continue trying to beat the campaign with my friend just so we can feel like we got our money's worth. reviewText:
One of the best Coop games around with a classic gameplay genre: roguelike hack 'n slashy, with four different maps to play on: two adventures, a survival campaign and a hero defense mode.

We can also consider this game a kind of RPG, expecially in the new Sun Temple campaign, where you can choose between  six total classes, each with their own abilities, skills and upgrades that you can get with the money and coins you can find in your journey, while you fight your way to clear the dungeons you're in from it's monsters and look for  the secret stuff that are waiting for you, all of this together with a golden soundtrack.

It may look that simple like this, but there is way more stuff in this game that i'm not going to spoil to you; you'd better find out by yourself, or also with your friends.

One of the best discoveries from the steam greenlight so far.

reviewText:
A good old fashioned dungeon crawler featuring: drop in drop out co op, several unique characters, and most amazingly NO CUTSCENES.

I was pleasantly surprised when I booted up the game as I scrolled through the options, there are resolutions from 600x800 all the way up to 4K. What more would you want? maybe a few post processing options to make the game appear as if it is being played on an old CRT monitor? the nerd in me exploded at the sight.

It features a campaign that is designed to last around two to three hours, but could be done quicker with serious practice. There is also a lot of strategy when it comes to which class you have picked specifically, such as when you are a priest in co-op ideally you should stick to your teammates; without them your combat skills are very limited. So you tailor your upgrades to support (levelling up healing, increasing movement etc.) and this really helps the characters actually progress. But as these reset every time you start a new game it still keeps the game fresh and allows new strategies to be tested out. I love playing Hammerwatch and recommend it to anyone who wants to have some fun with friends also.

5 Stars! Colours, Soundtrack is spot on, and controls feel great.

reviewText:
The search for a game to fill that hole left by Dark Souls continues to go on. Even though I had very much completed the game with about 700 hours of game time in, I still wasnâ€™t satisfied. Iâ€™d played Dark Souls 2 for a while, but it just wasnâ€™t the same as the first game. I know I picked up Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate and while Iâ€™m still playing the game, it doesnâ€™t quite fit the niche of what I was hoping for. I wanted a game which was as unforgiving and just as rewarding as Dark Souls with the same kind of co-op that would make me appreciate the power of friendship. Since there arenâ€™t too many games that copy that feel, I find myself diverging into the Roguelike genre. Just so it happens, the game Hammerwatch seemed to sell me right away.

Now, I donâ€™t usually delve into Roguelikes as theyâ€™re known for being intentionally and notoriously unfair and difficult. Theyâ€™re something I often play to challenge myself but theyâ€™re not something I would ever see as a party game. When I bought the game on sale for 8 dollars(including three other copies), Iâ€™d initially hoped to find three other friends to traverse the dungeons of the evil castle to fight with. Unfortunately, first impressions really let me down and I had to give away a few of my copies out of pure disappointment. Then, I had one person come up to me and offered to do some co-op to which I gave the one more chance to tickle meâ€¦and Iâ€™ll be damned if thatâ€™s not what happened.

Hammerwatch is a Dungeon Crawler Roguelike in which you are a member of 6 dungeoneers who have made their way into the titular castle. Though some adventuring is implied to have occurred, you have been cut off by the rest of your party and you are forced to find your own way out of the castle to meet up with the rest of the party. Your chances appear to be slim, however, as they deduce you are unlikely to get out alive. With what weapons and skills you have, though, you hack and slash your way through hordes of various creatures.

My initial run through the game was me starting as a Thief on standard difficulty and my first time going through the game could be described as very much challenging going alone. Enemies often come in mobs large enough that you can find yourself easily surrounded and have the psychic kind of AI where they can detect you from a fair distance, even if you were behind a wall. The experience ended abruptly when I discovered that you have that archaic lives system and dying results in permadeath. Upon this discovery, I learned of quite a few other features through research that deterred my desire to play anymore. It wasnâ€™t until my co-op experience that I entered the game a little too harshly.

When you start the game, you have a choice between six characters(two of which were added in later patching), two campaigns, a difficulty setting, and a series of modifiers that make the game customizable to the playerâ€™s comforts, making the game experience as hardcore or casual as youâ€™d like. Gameplay is simplified with one button for attacking and three skills to use. Unlike most RPGs, you do not level up by killing mobs. You actually go to merchants scattered throughout the campaign who you use gold to buy upgrades for your character. In most multiplayer experiences, collecting gold and treasure gets antagonistic. Fortunately, however, any gold you do pick up is gathered as a whole by the party and, better yet, you spend it as though it were separate.

If I had any complaints about the game, however, itâ€™s that the save feature can be unforgiving when playing with random players. If theyâ€™re especially uncoordinated and uncooperative like two players Iâ€™d played with, they basically wandered off and soloed areas, getting killed off and wasting respawns. It wasnâ€™t until I didnâ€™t respawn when I discovered that the other party members had burned out all our lives and had been spending the time upgrading themselves and saving the game before they quit. If youâ€™re playing with friends, this proves detrimental since saving doesnâ€™t reset your respawns or health. If you get game over and reload your save, you start off with the amount of health, mana, stats, players registered, and number of respawns you had from the last save, regardless of who saved the game last. If youâ€™re going to be playing with friends, Iâ€™d recommend making the game private.

Also, while four players are needed to make a balanced party, the ranger and priest are especially unbalanced in that the former is overpowered for going solo and the priest is so completely worthless by himselfâ€”this is because the priest canâ€™t heal himself when he starts out. The game was clearly made more for multiplayer in mind rather than single player which may make going through the game on your own a varying experience.

Overall, a lot of flaws and issues aside, the game, while repetitive at best, is definitely worth playing with friends, but Iâ€™d hardly recommend playing with random strangers or even the single player if youâ€™re the sort who wants a balanced experience going it alone. Itâ€™s definitely got a niched audience who is going to enjoy it, especially those who like Roguelikes. It's just a shame not many of my friends share that taste. Personally, Iâ€™m actually planning on starting over the solo mode with features to make it as dark souls-like as possibleâ€¦but then again, Iâ€™m just one of those self-loathing masochists who canâ€™t get enjoyment out of a game anymore if it doesnâ€™t somehow stop to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ on my face once in a while.

reviewText:
Pretty good, pretty good. Like Gauntlet, but modern.
Had a solid 4:37:52 playthrough on Hammerwatch Castle and 2:25:12 for Temple of the Sun, so for the price ($2.49 at the time of writing) it's definitely worth the money. There's some great community maps too.

However... survival and hero defense are definitely lacking.

For those that are unaware, Hero Defense is a mode where you're basically in a tower defense game... without towers. You fight for some twenty waves (give or take a few) until it's finally over: BORING! Beat it real fast :(

On to survival: grind central. Boring boring boring! Spent at least an hour through two games just running around killing things and trying to survive. I'm sure if it looked and sounded like Gauntlet, I would be okay, but it got pretty repetitive.

Overall I would have to give this game a 9.5, being generous to a few odd bugs that probably aren't common experience.
Play it. Die. Play again.

reviewText:
Got this gifted to me by my partner when it was on sale as something to muck around together on. Well worth the 5 bucks he spent for the 2 copies he bought. A decent selction of classes to play, something to suit everyone, and after starting over a small amount of times to find the classes for us we got started.

The level layouts are well put out, running around in places you have discovered but can't access as it is locked means that you really have to explore it all, that is where most of the play time comes from. Packs and packs of different types of mobs that change after each boss defeat. Secrets available on every level means that you have to keep an eye out or you miss so much.

The co-op game play was great fun for such a simple game, laughs were had about the stupidity of dying to basic stuff, and we really got to work as a team together, something that a lot of our games we play can no longer provide for different levels of play.

My one complaint is the boss fights, the first one was epic and we struggled for such a long time trying to get down pat the timing of the mechanics, after that though other bosses were lacking the wow factor.. Though the ending of the game was amusing.

I recommend this as something short term to play with friends, definitely a lot more fun with friends than alone.

reviewText:
I'm going to summarize the two main disadvantages to this game (note that these only apply to single player, and I have no knowledge of multiplayer at all):
1. The map is terrible.
In this game, each dungeon can last literally hours. That may not be too terrible in itself, except it takes even longer because the map screen does not allow you to see the whole dungeon that you've explored at once. The map only shows the areas nearby which you have already seen, and thus is severely limited in its usefulness. This can make exploring the full dungeon a nightmare. It can become a chore trying to find where to go next, sending you running in circles, simply because your map has practically no range beyond you.
2. The saving system and game over system are completely horrendous pieces of garbage.
You can have several save files, only one per character you start. The game works like this: you have several lives for your character, and if you lose them all, you completely game over and have to revert to your last save or revert to the very beginning of the game. That is complete rubbish. The saving works in that you have one save per character, as said before. You can't revert to old saves of that character. Any time you step on a checkpoint or go to another floor, your game is automatically saved. This hurts you, as if you find you have only one life left and critical health, this game becomes a joke between running to enemies and back to a save point, hoping to God you don't get hit even once. In my personal experience, I went into the first dungeon's boss room during single player. As a reminder, whenever you travel to another floor of a dungeon, your game automatically saves. However, this time, without any warning, the door in which I entered became locked, meaning that I was literally save-locked into the boss room. In a GOOD game, if you found the boss to be too advanced for you, you'd be given the opportunity to backtrack and get more upgrades so that you stand a chance against the boss later. However, in THIS game, since I die in literally two hits to the boss and I can't do anything about it, I have to restart an entire 2+ hours of gameplay, making sure I clear out even more of the dungeon than I did the first time. I'm sorry, game developers, but would it really kill you to take it more like a Legend of Zelda game? In LoZ, if you game over, you get sent back to the beginning of the CURRENT dungeon and all of the enemies are respawned, but you don't lose any upgrades, items, or progress throughout the dungeon. This is still a punishment for losing, but it doesn't make you redo literally hours of gameplay. Even the original Legend of Zelda on the now-archaic NES had this methodology, as Nintendo knew their audience wouldn't want to restart every detail of a long and difficult dungeon. You crazy guys instead, for the far worse, force someone to restart literally the whole game over in the case where they get save-locked into a fight they can't win. This is the kind of design people joke about from the NES era, and it seems you did not pick that hint up. Game-overing someone to the title screen is a joke. Stop using it. It's an easy way to kill a game.
Oh yeah, and remember that I haven't even tried multiplayer yet, and I've heard some terrible things about multiplayer. Since I have no experience of it, though, I'll give it the benefit of the doubt (or at least exclude it from this review).
It's a huge disappointment, as this game actually would be tremendous amounts of fun otherwise. The characters are unique, the fighting style is linear and remarkable, and the dungeons can hold many great secrets. I swear that if you simply made a better map to allow someone to see more of the dungeon at once, a better save system to allow people to revert to older saves on a character, and a better game over system that doesn't literally force you to do the entire game over again, this could easily become several times more enjoyable and popular.
Those things above shouldn't even take that much work to fix. If done with actual care, a developer wouldn't even have to edit any campaign levels.
Until the above are fixed for better enjoyability, I highly recommend that you, reader, STAY AWAY from this game. You'll find yourself addicted for a few good hours, then curse its name for such a crappy game over and save system. This game is not too old yet, so maybe the developers will take some heart and at least try to salvage it.
In short:
This game has tremendous potential, but it is horribly ruined by a bad saving and game over system, along with a map that doesn't help you get un-lost. Generally avoid unless you don't mind replaying literally hours over.

reviewText:
Excellent rendition of an old classic, if you have ever played GAUNTLET.

Definitely one to play and even more so with friends.

3 things to know before you do buy! IMPORTANT:

A. PAINFUL Button masher, i highly recommend finding a way to Auto-Fire/Rapid-Fire your buttons. Else its going to really hurt you in the long run. A program called AutoHotKey is a great one to help you get a auto-fire script working.

B. This game for some unknown reason has no frame-rate limit, so expect your computers temperatures to run HOT! VERY VERY HOT for no good reason (silly developers not putting a frame limiter into a 2D game...SILLY SILLY SILLY!!!). Highly recommend you lower the games resolution, and turn down its effects. OR if you know how to and can, underclock your system to stop it roaring up the temps.

C. Online game hosting needs knowledge of portforwarding. If you know how to do portforwarding, then youre fine, forward port #9995.

reviewText:
Not even the co-op was enough to make me think it was worth buying
I had already seen some game footage before playing it and I got convinced to buy by looking at it and thinking there would be much more in the game than that. And I also thought I was going to have a nice time improving my character and making him stronger. I was wrong.

reviewText:
The controls, graphics, animation, and general quality are really solid, but the content is spread far too thin and the game consists of mostly doing the same things over and over.  Occassionally you'll see old things mixed together in new ways - an enemy spawner next to a difficult stationary enemy, for example - but then that combination will get re-used dozens of times before you run into anything new, and that new thing may very well be a slightly faster version of an old enemy with different graphics. Tough enemies can take a minute to kill even if you're taking no damage and they pose no threat to you, making them more chore than threat, which only adds to the sense of tedium.

The difficulty is also extremely inconsistent.  Some enemies plink away with 1 damage and easily avoided attacks, while more difficult to avoid attacks often take half your life bar or more.  The game's first boss was vastly more difficult than the second.

I would have been happy to play this same game with levels a tenth as long and a constant stream of new situations, instead of its current form, which feels like mostly padding.

reviewText:
Someone made an exceptionally ugly and un-fun action RPG. How original. I understand I'm in the minority if you look at the Steam ratings. I just don't agree with them.

Hammerwatch is a fairly basic, straightforward action RPG. It's a dungeon crawl that compensates for the few enemy types with an overabundance of them. It's the same game that I've played and seen dozens of times. There are no new mechanics to speak of here. It's spam the attack button and clear out enemies. Rinse and Repeat. Careful positioning of your character and taking care to min/max your build is what's needed.

Here's the problem. That sounds like every other action RPG game in the last 20 years. In this case the devs decided that since they didn't have any graphical skills, they should just create ugly pixel blobs for everything and try to pass it off as retro". I saw better looking games on my Atari 2600. I'm not kidding either. I'm all for a unique and interesting art style. It doesn't have to have modern graphics. But I find these muddled and frankly dull. With the same kind of gameplay I've experienced a dozen times before

reviewText:
Move along, nothing to see here.

I understand it's supposed to be retro looking, that's not my reasoning for giving this a bad review, in fact, the game looks and sounds pretty decent. The problem here is that it's an updated version of the original Gauntlet with more RPG elements in it. And yes there is a secret level on Floor 2 that takes you right back to the first stage of Gauntlet as an homage to the original.

Problem is, Gauntlet actually evolved itself as a game to include a character and progression saving system in Gauntlet Legends and that was an Arcade game, so what's this game's excuse?

This goes right back to basics... like clear a 100 floor dungeon in a single sitting, if you lose all of your lives or actually manage to get a real life then you have to start over from stratch again... No thanks, I'll pass and find something more productive to do like watch paint dry.

Another gripe of mine, that's been occuring all too frequently in indie games lately, is the old school I.P. connection system which is just unaccetable at this point in gaming...

I mean really? I have to go open ports on my router because the developers decided to use an archaic connection design for their game... just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off already with this nonsense.

It's more trouble than it's worth as you'll probably be the last man standing and want to fall asleep after 40 minutes of this tripe.

When you're expecting to connect to your friends after first booting up the game and discovering you have to go play with ports... it's a bit disheartening. Honestly if I didn't already have Hamachi installed I would have just closed it and watched a movie instead... or maybe played a game with a server system.

I wouldn't pay more than a couple bucks for this game and if you're planning on beating it, hope to God your power doesn't go out or the game doesn't crash while it's minimized because no one has the kind of time or patience to complete this mess.

2 / 10

reviewText:
Simplistic in nature, which should be a good thing, but for Hammerwatch, it isn't. The game's presentation and story, within the first 45 minutes, is nowhere to be found. There's no goal beyond kill pixelated enemies and grabbing coins (which works for some games, but not in Hammerwatch's case). This type of beginning setup is only fun for the first playthrough, and quickly becomes stale afterwards.

Also, losing all your lives to an enemy or trap that you haven't yet learned how to overcome, and THEN being forced to start back at the very beginning of the game, is an extremely archaic function and has no place in the modern world of gaming. It absolutely killed my desire to go back and replay. This game isn't randomly generated and offers little incentive to return to it, and trudging through the snore-inducing level design was not going to happen.

Overall, Hammerwatch plays just how it looks - a game from 10 years ago.

reviewText:
In Hammerwatch, you'll fight hundreds of reskinned enimies, smash countless containers for coins, and solve simple puzzles.

Enemies are beaten in the same way: aggro, attack, and backpedal.   This cycle makes up the majority of the gameplay.  Larger groups can be killed as they vainly attempt to path around a corner.  It's trivial and boring.

It's important to be careful.  Groups of enemies can kill you in a few seconds so it's unwise to play recklessly.  Health restoring items are limited and if you run out of lives, you're forced to start all over.  Cautious play is required.

Money is acquired by smashing pots that litter the corridors.  It's not fun, but it's necessary to improve your character.  Some pots randomly have bombs hidden in them - what's the point?   It just makes the process more tedious.

Upgrades are purchased from shops scattered around the map.  For the most part, they're bland, numerical improvements.  On my Wizard, I increased my range, damage, and blast radius by roughly 20% across the board.  I also purchased the ability to combo.

By killing ten enemies in quick succession, your character is granted a buff that increases movement speed and damage.  This buff can be upgraded to provide minor healing and radial projectiles that fire every second.

However, as I previously mentioned, Hammerwatch punishes aggressive play.  The combo system doesn't really fit in a game where health needs to be conserved.

Loot consists of money, keys, health pickups, shop tokens, and small buffs to stats.  Shop tokens reduce the cost of upgrades by ~.5%.  Nothing here makes me want to play.

Hammerwatch is simply a boring game.  Any enjoyment from killing ememies is lost after the first couple hundred, it's annoying to scrounge for money, and character customization customization is dull.

If you're considering buying this game, watch a youtube video without a voiceover for ten minutes, and decide for yourself if it looks fun.

reviewText:
Hammerwatch is a nice looking rpg styled action game where you assume the role of a warrior, rogue, wizard or warlock.

Personally, I do not recommend this game because it's really shallow and gets tedious quite fast. The classes don't feel very unique, the fighting is simple button mashing and the puzzles are not that great to begin with. With some friends it's a tad more enjoyable but the horrible lag and netcode makes it hard to enjoy. It is actually quite impossible to get decent servers. After playing a while it just gets boring and it's not worth it.

reviewText:
This game was gifted to me, but I will review it as if I had purchased it for its standard price of $9.99. This is the definition of a hack n' slash. If you're into that genre of videogame, Hammerwatch is definitely for you. The graphics are poor of course, as it is developed by an unknown indie label named Crackshell. But that doesn't bother me as much as does the world (or lack of world I should say). The whole of a nearly 7-hour campaign took place underground in a single dungeon. I get that it's a dungeon-crawler, but at least change the setting of every few levels or something. Furthermore, it didn't have much variety when it came to the enemies you fought: scarabs or bats, take your pick. The only positive thing I can think to write about this game is the variety in classes. For the limited artwork, each class had an array of abilities that were quite aesthetically pleasing as they tore through hundreds of monsters at once. Also note that the game is planned to have a free DLC available sometime in the near future with implemented changes. Thus, be aware that they may fix some of the negatives I've mentioned above.

With that said, it is still not worth the full $10. If you are persistent in trying it, wait for one of Steam's bigger sales.

Thumbs down for now.

EDIT: The game recently updated and has introduced a new campaign set in a desert of sorts. Feel free to comment whether or not it's any good, as I have not yet had a chance to play it.

reviewText:
The most basic bird view perspective hack-and-slash with next to none redeeming factors.

First things first, it's by far not an ugly game. The retro graphics of this title seem to work out pretty well as they reflect on its minimalistic nature which btw.
is just as absolutely uninspiring as the generic battle music that plays in the background without context.

This is dungeon crawling striped down to it's bare bones.
No inventory, grindy/slow character progression, beyond-basic combat
that comprises of mashing the same melee/ranged-attack button over and over again.
Extremely inconsistent difficulty curve. There are hords of enemies that go down with one or two
hits yet swarms of tanky slugs that you will need to run from in order to avoid a barrage of projectiles. Later enemy encounters often feature combinations of previously fought ones untill they are used to death.
The level design is somewhat interesting as it's vast with quite a number of secrets to seek out
yet involves a lot of fetch-quests and levels are all in all way too long for what little gameplay they have to offer. Having 40 long achievements to unlock (Collect 1.000.000 coins...srsly?...) doesn't help in raising the playvalue/replayability one bit.

This title gets -1/10 I don't even"s from me.
I absolutely recommend to stay away from this title by all means. Avoid like the plague!"

reviewText:
This game is very aesthetically pleasing, the maps are well designed, and discovering secret areas is very satisfying.  Alas, those few positive traits are all the game has to compensate for the uninspired monotony of the core gameplay.  Disappointingly dull for an action game, disappointingly simplistic for an RPG, and incredibly repetative.

Since I'm tired and lazy like so many other steam users, I will now stop writing an actual review and just make a list of positives and negatives.

+Very good pixel art.  Always nice to see games where pixel art graphics are a stylistic choice, and not just used because it seems easier than other visual styles.
+The secrets make the game a lot more interesting on their own, and would increase replay value substantially if the core gameplay it was built on had any kind of nuance.

-If there's a tutorial of any kind, it's not immediately apparent.  Thankfully the controls aren't particularly complex, although they are a little odd by default.
-I don't think there's any story.  If there was, I wasn't made privy to it.  I don't need anything great, it doesn't even have to be a big part of the game, but really?  The only story I get at the start is an NPC across a broken bridge saying The bridge!"?  Not even a quick "the castle is overrun please save us!"?
-Thus far it seems the entirety of combat is handled with 2 buttons
date: one mana using ability and one main attack.  This might have been enough to make for an interesting game
recommended: but combat really ends up just being about mashing main attack button while trying to strafe
hoursPlayed: with the occasional special (usually just a higher damage attack of some sort) thrown in.\n-Repetative af\n-Slow movement makes for a dull action game"

reviewText:
I'll start with my veredict on this game: despite being addictive, it's not a well made game.


The gameplay: what most annoyed me in this game was that the designers didn't care a bit about explaining important things to players - the first example that comes to my head are potions: you found an yellow potion? that's cool, bro! now Alt+Tab and GOOGLE it 'yellow potion hammerwatch'. That adds to the amateur aura the game has because of its graphics (see below).

The gameplay(2): I don't think a game necessarily has to have a history, it actually annoys me. But Hammerwatch just drops you on a dungeon without a single word! It's just like that: this is you and this is your dungeon. Now walk and fight. It's pretty odd.

The graphics: they certainly made the increasingly commom mistake - they mistake retro visual style with ugly graphics. The colors haven't been well chosen, the sprites of the scenarios aren't attractive at all. Comparing this game's graphics with, for example, 8-bit-like-graphics Retro City Rampage puts this one to shame.

The audio: the soundtrack isn't really bad, but they could have come up with more tracks, because the loops make the current ones annoying.

The enemies: I remember playing Castlevania - Symphony of the Night and having to fight over 300 different kinds of foes. Meanwhile, in Hammerwatch, they didn't really feel like designing more than 5 different enemies for a game you take a few hours to complete. Oh
date: you think we should have made different foes? Well
recommended:
let's just give some of the existing ones a new color and more speed and health"

Co-op: You played for 2 hours with friends but you would like to change your class? FORGET IT! i mean: what's this guys' problem? Why can't i start with another character and no upgrades at all?
One of your friends has to leave and you and your remaining 2 friends wanna carry on playing? FORGET IT! start again just the 3 of you.

What's sad

reviewText: Hammerwatch is very nostalgic for any gamer. A classic 8 bit dungeon crawler with 4 classic classes: Archer, Wizard, Knight and Necromancer. They all have their own unique skills and fighting style. I must warn you though buyers...prepare to be kicked from games a lot if you decide to join others. I've tried a couple of times to make my own co-op games to avoid this but it seems to have a problem with that. Even with Hamachi in my experience with it. So with that said...there are plenty of losers on this game. I don't think this game is worth a full 9.99 price for how simple it is...I'd say 4.99 max; but you won't regret the purchase. It is really fun when you meet cool people.
